text: The CAMERA HOLDS ON the stained glass window. Beneath the painted figures is a scroll, and on the scroll, a part of stained glass window, is an inscription:

head_text.subj: I RUNNE TO DEATH AND DEATH MEETS ME AS FAST,
AND ALL MY PLEASURES ARE LIKE YESTERDAY. -

text: John Donne, Holy Sonnets VI. As the CAMERA CONTINUES TO HOLD, the jumbled sound of classroom recitations can be heard.
(o.s. from classroom above camera level) Amo, arias, amat, amamus, amatis, amant.
(o.s. from classroom below camera level) One times nine is nine. Two times nine is eighteen. Three times nine is twenty-seven. Four times nine is thirty-six
(o.s. from classroom above camera level, singing) Do, no, mi, Pa, sol, la, ti, do.

These classroom sounds, although they can be heard clearl should not disturb the serenity of the stairway or of the painted figures on which the CAMERA IS LEVELED. Suddenly, from overhead, a gong rings with a harsh, jarri noise. Doors are heard opening, feet scuffling over the f and the light, high sound of girls' voices chattering. A moment later a cascade of uniformed schoolgirls of all ag pours down the stairs past the camera. Against this tide single girl makes her way. The CAMERA PANS WITH her up the remainder of the short fl of stairs and across the hallway to a door marked, PRINCI The girl knocks and from inside an overВ— cultured woman' voice is heard in response,
Come in, please.

CLOSE SHOT - Mary Gibson at the door. She hesitates befor opening it. She is young and her youth gives her prettine but something in the quiet serenity of her face and the c candor of the eyes show the innate niceness of the girl; quality of character which will give her real beauty as s grows older. At the moment she is somewhat perplexed by h unexpected summons by the Head Mistress. MED. CLOSE SHOT of Mary as she opens the door and looks expectantly toward the desk. No one is there.
Here we are, Mary.

MED. LONG SHOT as Mary walks into the room. It is a large room and every effort has been made to invest it with authority. A large Sheraton desk with side trays stands a one end. On the wall behind this desk hangs a gloomy, dou visaged portrait of the founder of the school. The wall opposite the door is pierced by a large window. There are several bookcases with dull-looking volumes; books of reference and encyclopedia. On top of one of these cases the white, plaster head of Athena. The walls are covered enormous framed, sepia-tinted prints of the Acropolis, th Colosseum, Trajan's Column and other celebrated ruins. Mrs. Lowood, the Principal, a solidly built lady with iro gray hair and her assistant, Miss Gilcrist, a slim, frail lady of indeterminate age, are at a small table at the en the room. They are cutting out paper hearts. As Mary come to them, Mrs. Lowood finishes cutting out a paper heart a lays down the scissors with an air of satisfaction. With close behind her, she starts toward the desk. Miss Gilcri follows. The CAMERA PANS WITH them as they cross the room
I have a most painful matter to discuss with you, Mary.

Mary looks concerned. Mrs. Lowood has reached her desk, while Mary stands wonde what might come next. Mrs. Lowood deliberately seats hers and puts her fingertips together firmly. Over this Gothic arch she speaks to Mary. Miss Gilcrist takes her accustom place beside her.
Your sister - - have you heard from her lately?
No, Mrs. Lowood, she doesn't write often.
Have you any other relatives, Mary?
Mary shakes her head.
No. Jacqueline brought me up. (smiling) Somehow I never felt I needed other relatives.
Mrs. Lowood nods.
That makes it all the more difficult В—В—
(a little alarmed) Difficult? Has anything happened to Jacqueline?
We don't know, Mary. We've been unable to get in touch with your sister.
(relieved) Sometimes she can be quite careless. Why don't you try Mrs. Redi?

I have written repeatedly to Mrs. Redi. She vouchsafes no information whatsoever. (pauses) It is six months since your tuition has been paid, Mary. Naturally, it is impossible for you to stay on here as a paying pupil.
(in a small voice) Of course.

Miss Gilcrist and I have talked it over. You can remain here and work with the younger children as a sort of assistant teacher. These Valentine cut-outs for instance В—- (holds one up) -- it's something you could do.
She starts to get up as if everything were decided.
But, Mrs. Lowood, I can't just stay here not knowing what's happened to my sister. Maybe if I went to New York -- if I saw Mrs. Redi myself --

I doubt if you'll get anything out of that woman. But if (shrugging) you'd like to try, I'll advance you the money to make the trip to New York. Of course, my dear, if you don't find your sister, you can always come back here.
(catching the note of high minded dismissal) Thank you.
She turns and starts for the door. Miss Gilcrist goes wit her.
Mary comes out of Mrs. Lowood's office, closely followed  by Miss Gilcrist, who closes the door softly behind her.
Mary, don't come back. No matter if you never find your sister -В— no matter what happens to you -- don't come back.
Mary looks at her in surprise.
(in a kindly, more explanatory tone) My parents died when I was a pupil. I left, as you are leaving, but I didn't have courage -- one must have courage to really live in the world -- I came back.

The two stand looking at each other for a moment, while M realizes what her future may be -- what Miss Gilcrist is then suddenly the ringing notes of Mrs. Lowood's voice co from the other side of the door.
Gilcrist!
Miss Gilcrist starts, turns automatically to open the doo then looks back at Mary. With a fond glance, she pats her before opening the door and going on into Mrs. Lowood's office.

The stained glass window. The rain pours against the glas and the boughs of the tree beat back and forth. Mary come down the stairs dressed in plain travelling clothes. She carries her bag in one hand. She hears the familiar sound daily classroom recitations.
Je cherche Tu cherches Ell cherahe Nous cherohons Vous cherchez Elba cherohent
The French lesson dies away and we hear Mrs. Lowood's voi
Agnes --- ! John Quincy Adams did not follow John Adams as President.

Mary smiles. In the distance some young girl's fingers fa awkwardly over the melancholy chords of Traumerei. Mary reaches the bottom of the stairway and passes the big, fu oak grandfather's clock which stands with majestic infini of time, reminding all tardy students that it is later th they know. As she passes it, it rings the hour. She looks its friendly, familiar face, and gives it a little pat of farewell. O.S. we hear a sweeping girl's voice reciting t final verse of "The Chambered Nautilus."

Build thee more stately mansions, 0 my soul, As the swift seasons roll; Leave thy low-vaulted past! Let each new temple, nobler than the last Shut thee from heaven with a dome more vast, Till thou at length art free, Leaving thins outgrown shell by life's unresting sea;;
With this burst of poetic encouragement, Mary crosses the hallway, opens the door and passes out of Highcliffe Acad closing the door behind her.

MED. CLOSEUP of a column of white powder falling from an oscillating sifter. The powder falls into a large barrel, the column of powder and its attendant dust hide from vie the three figures behind it. We hear the throaty voice of Mrs. Redi.
That's enough.

There is a click as the apparatus is turned off. The powd stops falling. Three people are disclosed. Mary, still in travelling suit; Mrs. Redi, a neat, businesslike woman, w firm features and a steady eye. Her hair is extremely well coifed. Not a strand is out of place. Her clothes are covered by a long, white surgeon' coat of immaculate linen. The third person is a workman, dressed in a white smock and wearing a long, snouted, inhalator mask, which he removes, revealing a benign and smiling face. Mrs. Redi rubs a bit of the powder on the palm of her han She examines it critically.
(to Joseph) It seems all right, Joseph.  (turning to Mary with a strained smile) You see, we do keep up the quality of La Jeunesse products in spite of Jacqueline's absence.
She and Mary start down the line of machines toward a fun and tube arrangement set up for filling bottles. The CAME DOLLYS WITH them.
(as they go, evidently resuming a previous discussion) But you must know someone who has seen or heard of my sister.
(coldly) I'm afraid not.
They reach the bottle-filling apparatus. Mrs. Redi lifts of the bottles and holds it up to the light.
Your sister had many friends --but they were not my friends. I was only the manager of her plant.

She sets down the bottle and they move on. The CAMERA GOE WITH them. Mary, embarrassed, looks at her. They have rea a machine which pours luke-warm cleansing cream into grea jars. As one of the jars slides out from the machine, Mrs Redi picks it up, rubs a bit of cream from the top of the onto the back of her hand, and judges the rapidity with w the cream dissolves at body temperature. Evidently it mee with her approval, for she passes on and goes toward her office. Mary goes with her. At the door they stop a moment.
Mrs. Redi, there's one thing В—-with Jacqueline gone, how do you carry on the business? What do you do with the receipts? How do you sign checks--?
(smiling) Mary, I'm amazed. Didn't Jacqueline tell you? She sold the business to me at least eight months ago. It's my business now.
I didn't know.
(still smiling) Yes В—В— and I must say I've done very well with it -- perhaps even better than Jacqueline.

They move on toward Mrs. Redi's office. INT. SALON - LA JEUNESSE -DAY. 8Mary and Mrs. Redi come into the salon. Beauty operators at work on patrons in several of the booths. The modernis glass walls, some patterned with stripes, the mirrors, an the gleaming gadgets make of this ordinary room a rather fantastic and distorted place.
There's nothing you can think of -- old letters, anything, that might give me some hint as to where I might find Jacqueline?
Leave me your address, and if I find anything, I'll get in touch with you.
I'm stopping at the Chatsworth.
(with an air of dismissal) Thank you, my dear.
Mrs. Redi puts her hand on the knob of the door marked "OFFICE." Mary starts off.

Mary passes through the salon. As she passes one booth, a young woman in the white smock of an operator comes out. is Frances, a tense, nervous young woman, with bleached b hair and excited, nervous eyes..
(with great friendliness) Why, Mary --
Hello, Frances.
How's Miss Jacqueline?
I don't know. That's why I came to see Mrs. Redi. I'm trying to find her.
You mean Miss Jacqueline's gone, and you don't know where she is?
Mary nods. Frances beckons to Mary, and they pass through side door into a corridor that connects the plant with th street.
It is a narrow, gloomy passage. The two girls come into i from the side door. Frances fishes a package of cigarette from her pocket, takes one, lights it as she speaks.
I don't get this. Miss Jacqueline was always so fond of you -- she was always talking about you -В— had your picture in her office.
I know. For the first time I'm beginning to be frightened. I almost feel as if I'd never known my sister.
Nothing's happened to her. It's just that I can't understand her not getting in touch with you.
I can't understand it at all.
Well, don't worry. I saw Miss Jacqueline only a week ago. I saw her at a little restaurant the boy friend took me to -- an Italian place down in the Village В—-        "The Dante."
"The Dante?"
It's on Peary Street. Just ask the people who run it. They'll remember her. (with reminiscent pride) People who see Miss Jacqueline never forget her.
I'll try there.

She starts to return to the salon, but Frances indicates her there is a short cut to the street by means of the lo hallway. The two girls smile at each other. Frances turns back into the salon and Mary starts down the corridor.

Mary comes out of the side entrance and passes the displa window. She looks up for a moment at the words "La Jeunes and at the peculiar trade-mark of the company. It is on t peculiar tradeВ—mark, a geometric figure, that the scene

It is after three o'clock, and the street is alive with children. A covey of them flash past on roller skates, ta by one poor urchin with only one skate, who strives desperately to keep up with the tail end of the processio Mary, coming around the corner, has to draw back half a s to got out of his way. A horseВ—drawn laundry truck stands at the curb on the opposite side of the street, and a man is busily lifting bundles of soiled wash. On the other side Of the street i the Dante. It is an Italian restaurant, a half-flight bel the street level. The name and the word "Restaurant" are written on the glass in gold letters. In the lower left hand corner of the window is a cardboar sign, hand-lettered to read "Rooms for Rent". Above the doorway is a poly-chrome bust of Dante. Mary crosses the street to enter the Dante. A young man, Jason Hoag, comes around the corner. He is a man about thirty-five years ol and rather poorly dressed in an ordinary business suit an trench coat  Under one arm he carries a load of books. He stops and looks at Mary with interest. She continues on, going down the steps, under the Dante statue, and into th restaurant. Jason looks after her.

This is a fairly good-sized room, with benches along the walls and many small tables. Along one wall is a crudely painted mural, a reproduction of the famous painting whic shows Dante's first meeting with Beatrice. Dante is passi along the cobbled street, and Beatrice, with two companio large, flourishing wenches, is casting him a coy look ove her shoulder in passing. Directly under the feet of the p is a small table for one patron. On a back counter stands enormous, shining metal coffee machine. This is a patente contraption for making coffee. The entire machine is contrived to serve only one small purpose В—В—to make a c coffee by driving steam through ground coffee. Near this machine and flanking the door into the kitchen are fake p in wooden tubs. There is a door leading to the house hall and through this door we can see the newel post of the stairway leading to the rooms above. On most of the table platters of antipasto have been arranged in readiness for dinner hour. When Mary enters, the restaurant is empty, b echoes to the sound of a rich female voice singing with g sentimental emphasis the words of "Care Mio Ben." Mary lo around, hesitates a moment, and then starts toward the ba of the restaurant, as if following the source of the sing At the swinging door which separates the restaurant from kitchen Mary hesitates a moment, then knocks timidly. The singing continues, and realizing that her knock will not heard above it, Mary shyly pushes open the door.

This is a cluttered, busy, steaming kitchen. In one corne a little table Mr. Romari, the proprietor, in a waiter's uniform, is busily folding napkins. Mrs. Romari herself f whose bosom come the sounds of "Caro Mio Ben," can be seen through a cloud of steam behi boiling, kettle of spaghetti. She is a tall, gracious Ita of sentiment and humor. Her pet pigeon in close attendanc her feet. This bird follows her wherever she goes, hoppin about the floor at her heels. As Mrs. Romari wants to lif kettle of spaghetti from the stove and carry it to a cent table, she softly kicks the pigeon out on her way with a practiced backward sweep of her slippered foot. Her turn brings her face to face with Mary as she enters. Both the Romaris look at her questioningly.
I'm worry to bother you. I want to ask you about my sister.
(getting up) Yes?
I thought you might know her. She was seen here about a week ago. Her name is Jacqueline Gibson.
(shrugging) I don't know no Gibson. This is a restaurant. Many people come here.
She's very beautiful.
Romari shrugs again.
I wish I could tell you what she looked like -- I know you'd remember her, She is tall --with dark hair --
Romari shrugs. This all means nothing to him.
Once you'd seen my sister you'd never forget her.
(interrupting; to Romari) Giacomo -- la bellisslina madonna В—-
Maybe.
(to Mary) Let me look at you -- you could be her sister
(smiling) Yes В—В— yes, if she made that much impression on you, I'm sure it was Jacqueline.
She's not been here for a long time.
But she was here?

Oh yes, yes. One day a beautiful car comes here. This beautiful lady in furs gets out. There is a handsome man with her, and the chauffeur  The lady rents one of our upstairs rooms. The chauffeur changes the lock on the door. Then the lady never comes back --not to live, anyhow. She came back three, four times, but always alone and just to eat.
Mary shakes her head in puzzlement.
You mean she just came here, rented the room, locked it, and left?
Yes -- and pays the rent every month.
Could you let me see that room? If it is hers, there might be something there to help me find my sister.
(shaking his head) No -- the rent in paid. The lady asked us to promise, I wouldn't open the door.
Please.
Romari shakes his head.
(turning to Mrs. Romari, pleading) It's important
Mrs. Romari looks at her kindly.

Mary and the Romaris. It is a bleak hallway with a narrow strip of worn carpet running down the exact middle of the floor space. A picture of St. Francis of Assisi, surround by fluttering white birds, hangs on the wall, a little bi askew. Mrs. Romari and Mary stand near the stairway raili with the pigeon in close attendance on Mrs. Romari. Romar with a toolbox at his feet, is at the door, on which is t number "7". He has taken off the bottom hinge and is now striking a last few blows to remove the pin from the top hinge. As he works, a girl -- Mimi -- crosses in the background one hallway door to another. She is a tall, thin blonde a is wearing a faded bathrobe. She has a handkerchief over lips, and is coughing dismally. She closes the door behin her.
Fo come ti pare. To desiderare sempre di vedere che cosa c'era in quella stanza.
(turning to Mrs. Romari) What did he say?
(translating) He says he always wanted to see the inside of that room anyway.
The top hinge comes off. Mr. Romari opens the door, and t three press forward.

The CAMERA IS SHOOTING OVER the shoulders and PAST the ha lost profiles of Mary and the Romaris, as they look into room. It is a room that is empty except for two objects. a pipe overhead is suspended a hangman's noose and beneat stands a little gilt chair. There is nothing else.

MED. SHOT of Jason Hoag. He is standing shyly beside the coffee machine while Mr. Romari draws a cup of the coffee Jason watches Romari while he pulls the various levers, releases the clouds of steam and finally pulls out the li demiВ—tass and puts it on a little tray. While Jason watc he listens to conversation going on nearby.

I tell you, young lady, when a thing like this comes up, you've got to go to the police. What do you think people pay taxes for? I ain't just to keep us chasing after crooks and regulating traffic. We're supposed to help everybody. You gotto go to the police about your sister, Miss.

Romari starts out of scene with the little cup of coffee. CAMERA PANS with him as he brings the coffee to Mary who seated with Mrs. Romari at one of the tables under the mu A policeman stands beside them. The policeman is in a hea blue sweater, with his coat over his arm, his uniform cap the back of his belt and all the metal weight of his impedimenta can be seen hanging from his belt, handcuffs, revolver, billy, etc. Jason comes hesitantly into the sce He addresses the policeman.
I've had some experience with the Bureau of Missing Persons
Yeah -- well, Mr. Hoag, lost persons are the concern of the Missing Persons Bureau.
You're a poet, Jason. You stick to your poetry.
In a way that makes everything my business.
(a little hesitantly to Jason) Were you going to make a suggestion?
Yes. I was going to tell you to look into your own heart -- do you really want to find your sister?
Mary looks affronted. Mrs. Romari bursts out laughing in good humor.
Ah, my Jason -- always laughing -- always trying to help others. (to Mary) He's a good boy, Miss -- he just talks that way.
(with a little smile to Mary) I'm a good boy, but no one listens to what I say.
You do what I tell you, young lady, and go to the Missing Persons Bureau for your sister.
(turning from Jason to the policeman and starting to rise) If you'll give me the address.

FULL SHOT. A long counter divides the room in half. On on side are the filing cabinets, records, and office equipme used by the policemen who service this heartbreak house. Behind the desk, protected by steel wickets, sit half a d policemen taking down dates. CAMERA DOLLIES SLOWLY FORWARD parallel to the counter. As moves along, we hear the voice of the petitioners describ their loved ones. The same flat, unemotional professional voice seems to as the routine questions at each of the different wickets.
She was only sixteen --
Had she ever run away before?
What did he have on when last seen?
(tearfully) He went out without his hat or his coat. It's very cold for such an old man -В—
Any identifying marks or characteristics, scars, amputations, tattoo marks, speech impediments?
No, none.
CAMERA DOLLIES UP to the        last wicket where Mary st
Any further details?
She sold her business about eight months ago to Mrs. Esther Redi.
What relation are you to the missing person?
Sister.
Sign here.

Mary starts to sign. REVERSE ANGLE - on the other side of the wicket. Two men stand in the f.g., but not together. In the b.g. we see Mary's back as she signs the police report. The man in th center is Paul Radeau, a big man with iron-gray hair. He appears entirely oblivious of everything around him. The second man is Irving August, a skip-trace artist. His derby is dulled by the mists of many winters, and his dark eyes are fastened upon Mary. It is obvious that he h been listening as she made out her report. Mary finishes signing the report and turns away from the wicket. She ta scarcely more than a single step when she finds herself confronted by Irving August, who smiles at her.
I'm Irving August, private investigator. I think I can help you. Here's my card.
He produces a business card which he hands to Mary. Mary takes the card and glances at it as August continues.
The name may not mean anything to you, young lady, but say the word and I'll have your sister for you in forty-eight hours.
(impressed) You can?

(gesturing expansively) Look, sister', Manhattan is only nine miles long and four and one  half miles wide. I ain't never been off it. I know it like you know your own back yard. You get me a small retainer --say fifty bucks, and I'll get your sister for you. I guarantee
I haven't any money but I'll get a job and --
Irving August's enthusiasm vanishes.
Lady, this kind of work costs money. I got to cover all the hospitals, the morgue -- that's the first place you got to go and it ain't pleasant -- the morgue -В—

He finishes his speech by shaking his head. Mary turns aw and goes out of scene. August is standing, staring disgustedly after her when a hand touches him on the shou and he turns to face Paul Radeau.
You know who I am, August?
(suddenly tense and cautious) Sure I do.
Then you know that if I give you a little advice, it'll be good advice.
Yeah В—- sure.
That girl was looking for Jacqueline Gibson. I'd forget it if I were you.
Okay, Mr. Radeau, it's forgot.

Radeau nods appreciatively and goes ponderously away. Irv August watches him go, his eyes sharp with avarice and suspicion. With quick steps, August crosses to the wicket where Mary had given her report.
Hey, Danny, get me the file on Jacqueline Gibson, will you?
The policeman turns to the file.

The bulwarks and gangplank are in the f.g. The street and wharf at river level. Beyond that there are the sidewalk the two doors leading into the morgue. The river is not s although the sound of tugboat and barge whistles comes o. The street and sidewalk are wet, as if a drizzling rain h recently fallen, One of these doors is open and from it c a procession of dock workers carrying cheap pine coffins. other door is closed, Above both doors are printed the wo

Over the door from which the pine boxes are being taken i another legend carved into the stone: HE CALLETH ALL HIS CHILDREN BY THEIR NAME. Out of the second door Mary emerges. Her face is white an drawn. With a shudder she wraps her coat about her and st walking, bracing herself against the fresh, cold gusts of wind blowing from the river. A barge whistle sounds o.s. dismally.
MED. SHOT Mary Gibson and Miss Summers, the receptionist, Miss Summers wears hornВ—rimmed glasses and a oriijp whit shirtwaist. In front of her is a plaque with the inscript
Miss Summers is reading questions from a form reception p and filling out the answers.
Whom do you wish to see?
Mr. Gregory Ward, please.
And what is it about, Miss Gibson?
(her voice almost a whisper) A personal matter В—В— I was given Mr. Ward's name --
May I ask who gave you his name?
Mary thinks a moment, and as she thinks all the horror of trip to the morgue and what she has seen        is reflec her face and voice.
The morgue В—В—
Miss Summers looks up at her in surprise, but already Mar beginning to faint. As she crumples, we IRIS OUT.
IRIS IN on a CLOSEUP of Mary's face as seen through a glass of water which she is sipping, Gregory Ward is hold the glass and over the shot we hear his voice.
Do you feel all right?

CAMERA PULLS BACK to include Gregory Ward seated beside M who is reclining on a couch in his office. He is a man in middle thirties, handsome and wellВ—dressed in a quietly, professional way. He takes the glass away from Mary's lip and passes it to Miss Summers who is beside him.
I feel like an idiot В—В— fainting in a stranger's office.
Miss Summers, with a considerate look to see that Mary is right, starts out of the room with the glass of water.
(smiling) We're not exactly strangers, Mary. Jacqueline spoke about you often. I suppose she told you about me,
No...At the morgue they told me a Mr. Gregory Ward had made inquiries about Jacqueline.
The Morgue? No wonder you fainted. (he pauses) I wish you had come to me first.
Then you know where Jacqueline is?
(shakes his head negatively) But I'd give a great deal to know.
(spunkily) Why?
(smiling) I love your sister, Mary. I love her very much.
There is a little silence while Mary looks at him steadil then she half smiles. He leans over and pats her hand.
It's easy to understand now, isn't it?
Mary nods.

(speaking in a low voice, almost as if to himself) A man would look anywhere for her, Mary. There is something exciting and unforgettable about her -В— something you never get hold of В—- something that keeps a man following after her.

Because I loved Jacqueline I thought I knew her. Today I found out such strange things В—В—frightening things. I saw a hangman's noose that she had hanging -В— waiting В—В— I feel as if I'd never known her.
(smiling) At least I can explain that, Mary. Your sister had a feeling about life В—В— that it wasn't worth living unless one could end it. I helped her get that room.
Weren't you afraid?

Afraid she might commit suicide? (he shakes his head) People who commit suicide don't talk about it. That room made her happy in some strange way I couldn't understand. She lived in a world of her own fancy. She didn't always tell the truth. In fact -В— I'm afraid she didn't know what the truth was. (he pauses for a moment, and looks at Mary) There were many things about Jacqueline I didn't understand, and yet, without understanding, I had to be with her В—В— to see her В—В— to touch her В—В— in order to be happy. It's hard to explain to a youngster.
(a little sharply) I'm not a youngster. I can understand.
He looks at her.
The colors returning to your cheeks. You look as if you were coming back to life. Are you sure you didn't faint because you were hungry?
Mary looks astonished, and then laughs to herself.
You know...I didn't have lunch.
He looks at his wristwatch, and chuckles.
It's nearly six. Time for dinner, I'd say.
He extends his hand to her to help her up. She takes it.
DOLLY SHOT of Mary and Gregory Ward as they come up along street in front of the hotel. There is a very heavy mist Ward carries an umbrella.
Thank you. It was a lovely dinner.
Good.
(thoughtfully) But I reel guilty. It doesn't seem right for me to enjoy myself with Jacqueline gone.
Gregory looks at her.
You can't make it your life's work looking for Jacqueline. (with a smile) ) You'll have to do other things... live...get some enjoyment out of life. I hope you'll let me help you.
(smiling) Thank you.. .goodnight.
Goodnight, Mary.
He tips his hat and turns away, as she starts in to the hotel.
It is a conventional hotel lobby. Mary comes in, and as s crosses the lobby, flrving August rises from a straight b chair set against a pillar, and comes to meet her.
I've been waitin' for you Miss Gibson. I want you to know I've decided to take your case.
Mr. August, I'm not at all sure -
(interrupting) Look. Don't say a word. I've taken an interest in you and I'm willin' to put up my time to help you. Besides, I think I know where to find your sister.
Where?
Wait a minute. This has got a lot of angles. You've got to take it easy. Do you know a Mrs. Redi?
Yes. She bought my sister's business.
That's what she told you. I looked it up at the Hall of Records. Your sister deeded her the business as an outright girt.
Why would Mrs. Redi lie to me?

That's what I tried to find out.        I went to La Jeunesse В—В— (he mispronounces as badly as he can) -- used a phony health inspector's badge В—В— they let me go through the works -- all but one room. That room was locked. I'd like to see the inside of that room.
You think my sister is there?
You can't tell.
Can we go there now?
Sister, you can't just go breaking into places. There's a night watchman down there and locks on the door.
If my sister's in that room, it won't make any difference about warrants- and things, I want to go there.
(thoughtfully) I don't know if I want to go with you or not.
Mary starts out and, a little reluctantly, August follows her.

Mary and August come across tho street and look in the windows of the cosmetic company. Only the night lights ar burning in the salon. August tries the door rather perfunctorily. He shakes his head, and with Mary, moves o the side door leading into the passageway. From his pocke takes a bunch of keys and tries one after another. Finall one key works and the door swings open. Mary stops in ahe of August.

TWO SHOT of Mary and August. August softly closes the doo behind him. The street light shines through the glass upp ha-if of the door and invades the dark hallway for a shor distance. They walk softly forward to the place where thi light ends abruptly in the darkness. Here Mary pauses. Au looks at her.
I don't like this.
Which room is it?
It's the last door at the end of this hall.
Mary starts forward a step or two, the shadows closing ar her until only her face is still in the light. August fol her. She stops and looks off into the darkness.
You scared?
Yes.
Let's get out of here.
No.
They stand a moment in silence.
You could go on, Mr. August. You could open the door. I'd stay right here.
August shakes his head.
It's only a little way, Mr. August.
I'd like to get out of here.
No.
They stand again silently looking down the dark corridor.
We can't stand here all night.
You could go and open the door.
Listen В—В—

Realizing the futility of argument, he breaks off what he going to say, shrugs, and starts down the dark passage. M watches him and retreats a stop or two toward the street order to have the comforting light around her again. She stands there while August's footsteps recede in the darkn

A night watchman, an old man wearing a worn corduroy Norf jacket and a battered hat, with his time clock hanging fr broad strap around his neck, comes out of a neighboring store, a flower shop. He carefully closes the door behind and goes to the entrance of La Jeunesse. From a key ring hanging from the leather clock strap he selects one key a begins to open the door.

Mary still stands in the patch of light near the doorway. Abreast of her is the doorway leading from the hall to th salon. Through the glass upper half of the door, she sees gleam of light in the other room and tiptoes up to the do and looks out.

From Mary's angle, shooting through the window, can be so the night watchman, the beam of his flashlight coursing a of him as he makes his way to a time clock. Ho rings in h clock. MED. CLOSE SHOT В— Mary, nervous and apprehensive, looks through at the night watchman. She makes a decision and starts off along the hallway to warn August. She disappea in the blackness of the unlit portion of the hallway. REVERSE SHOT. At the far end of the hallway the illuminat square of the street door can be seen, and the little pat of light near it  Nearer the CAMERA a broad streak of lig from a partially open door is between the darkness and th CAMERA. Mary comes out of tho darkness and into this ligh At the same moment, August comes out of the partially ope door, blocking out the light for a minute. His shadow goe ahead of him - contorted and strange. He stands a moment before Mary; both of his hands clenched tightly against h stomach. She speaks to him in a whisper.
Mr. August -- the night watchman
August makes no answer, but starts walking blindly, swayi little, toward the street door. Mary goes with him, walki at his side, trying to peer into his face.
The night watchman -- he is in the salon.
Still August pays no attention.
Mr. August, what is it? What's the matter?

There is no answer. Ho continues to walk in the same jerk painВ—gripped fashion, slowly and unsteadily, toward the light. They are engulfed in the darkness. MED. CLOSE SHOT - August and Mary from the street angle, they come out of the darkness. Mary is very agitated and worried. August still continues to plod blindly forward. reaches out to touch his shoulder.
Mr. August --

Her hand touches his shoulder. Almost as if unable to bea this trifling weight, he collapses suddenly at her foot. looks down. CLOSEUP of Irving August's arm on the floor. It is sprawl awkwardly out  The sleeve is darkly stained, and there is widening stain of blood upon the floor. Mary's slippered step back so that the blood will not touch her. Mary screams. The narrow hallway rings, echoes and reecho with the sound. Mary runs wildly toward the door, fumbles with the knob a pulls it brusquely open. As she does so, the beam of the night watchman's searchlight comes in from the loft. O.S. wild bell starts to ring madly as Mary bolts in panic.

location: STREET IN FRONT OF LA JEUNESSE

text: Mary comes out of tin deer and starts running down the street. Behind her the lights of both the hall and the sa blaze. The bell rings o.s. she looks ever her shoulder an continues running.

Mary, still running, comes down the street. She looks bac for a moment and then goes down the stairs to the subway. The CAMERA REMAINS on the subway entrance a moment so tha can be clearly seen that this entrance is marked:

It is late, and this particular car is almost empty. Ther Mary, .sitting huddled in one corner under the map of the route which the I.R.T. so thoughtfully provides. Mary sit still and white, obviously shaken. Her coat collar is dra protectively against her throat. Opposite her are a pair young lovers, their hands clasped, who look blissfully in each others eyes. The conductor comes shambling into the car. He leeks at M and takes a step toward her, teetering on practiced tees, disdaining the overhead strap.
You know where you're going, lady?
Mary nods.
You've been to the end of the line and back again -- hope you enjoyed the ride.

He passes on. Mary looks after him, frightened. As he rea the end of the car, the subway train begins to come to a step. The two lovers get up, their hands still tightly clasped. INSERT A SIGN reading:        "14TH STREET" BACK TO SCENE. The train comes to a stop. Mary glances up The subway door glides open. The two lovers sidle crab-wi through it, never relinquishing their clasps on each othe hands, and through this same door come three men, three convivial drunks. GROUP SHOT of the three drunks as they seat themselves opposite Mary. The middle drunk carries the heaviest load The ether two support him, laughing and rearing as they m him comfortable between them. All three wear top hats and dark overcoats  The hat of tin man in the middle is tilte over one eye. MED. CLOSE SHOT of Mary as she looks at the three men acr from her. Over this shot comes the sound of the subway tr stopping. THREE SHOT of the three men. One of them leans across the supposedly drunken man between them to offer a light for ether's cigarette. The man in the middle lolls awkwardly, swaying- between them. CLOSEUP of Mary as she stares at the man in the middle. S familiar chord of memory is touched in her mind. THREE SHOT of the three men. . The car jolts and the hat slides off the middle man's head. We see that the man is Irving August, and that he is dead. One of the men quickl reaches down, picks up the hat and puts it back on August head. CLOSEUP of Mary. Her fear is confirmed. Looking around he cautiously, she gets up and starts down the aisle. At the of the car she leeks back. FULL SHOT - the three men sitting at the opposite end of car. One of the men is whispering to the other man pointi to Mary. FULL SHOT of Mary as she quickly opens the door and goes the next car. She walks down the length of the car. A man sleeping. She shakes his shoulder.
Please --- please В—В—
The man only mutters something in his sleep. Mary continu down the car's length to where a drunken girl sits, her h lolling.
I want your help, please.
The drunken woman merely looks at her blankly. The cars a coming to a stop again. The door opens and the conductor comes through. Mary seizes his arm.
These men in there В—В— don't let them get out.
What's the matter now?
One of them has been murdered!
The conductor looks at her dubiously. The cars have come stop. He looks into the next car and then glances down at her.
(crossly) What men?

Mary turns and looks back toward the car she just left. LONG SHOT of the car as Mary sees it. It is completely deserted. TWO SHOT        - Mary and the conductor. The subway trai starting to move again.
But they were there.
The conductor looks at her and merely observes.
Yeah.
MED. CLOSE SHOT of a newspaper vender calling:
Wuxtra! Murder! Murder! Read all about it!

He is standing directly in front of the revolving doors a behind him, through the glass of the doorway, we can see waiting, her face anxious and strained as she peers out o the street. A constant stream of passersby goes by the building. Out of this stream Gregory Ward emerges, goes through the revolving doors, and we see him met by Mary, begins excitedly to talk to him. He shakes his head, take her arm and walks her off.

This is a very small counter and stand with a few tables the window -- the sort of restaurant that is open only fo breakfast and lunch and is patronized by office workers w can content themselves with a sandwich and a cup of coffe The scene opens on the newsboy as he comes into the restaurant and goes up to the counter. The waiter behind counter buys a paper and brings it with an order of one c of coffee and a glass of milk to Mary and Ward, who are sitting at a small table. The newsboy goes on outside and over the scene from time to time we hear his voice crying "Murder! Read all about it!" Gregory Ward takes the glass of milk and slides it down t counter in front of Mary. He opens up the paper and scans carefully. Mary watches him anxiously, and turns to him.
This is about another murder В—В— a woman at Fifty Second Street
But you do believe me?
(after a little pause) The important thing is, the police won't believe you.

I saw him on the floor. He was cut -В— (indicates her own belly) --here. The blood was running out. He was dead. I'm sure of it.  Then on the subway I saw him В—В— white В—В— and the men holding him up between them.
Gregory takes a sip of his coffee and speaks gently, but unable to hide his disbelief.
Yes, of course В—В— but the police would say you'd probably had a bad dream.
He was a kind little man in his way В—В— and I made him go down that hall into the darkness. I made him do it.
Drink your milk.
Mary looks up, startled at this note of command.
I don't like to be ordered to do anything.
Gregory looks at her for a moment.
I'm sorry. I didn't intend to treat you like a child.
But you have treated me that way.
I won't do it again. We're friends. I'll never order you about again.
He puts out his hand and Mary takes it.
(smiling) However, I won't say that I'll not take charge occasionally, and I'm going to take charge new. I've a job for you.
A job?
You told me you were pretty good with youngsters. Today I bumped into an old friend of mine, Mrs.  Wheeler  She runs a settlement house down in the Village and is looking for a kindergarten teacher.
I'd like that.
It's not much money, but it's enough to live on. You'd have to move out of that hotel and into a furnished room.
Maybe the Romaris might have a room. They seem nice.
The people at the restaurant?
Yes.
Gregory starts getting up, looks at his watch.
If you want, I've time to take you down to see Mrs. Wheeler right now.
Mary gets up. They stay for a moment while he gets change of his pocket and gives it to the counter man.
A dark, handsome man with bold, insolent eyes lounges carelessly before the reception desk. Miss Summers puts d the phone and smiles up at him.
Mr. Ward will see you in just a few minutes. Won't you wait, Dr. Judd?
Thank you.

He takes out his cigarette case, selects a cigarette, but no matches. Miss Summers gives him her lighter. He lights cigarette and crosses the room to sit down on the waiting room couch. Throughout the scene he toys with the lighter his hand. Miss Summers looks across et him for a moment, then, after a little hesitancy, she speaks.
Dr. Judd?
Judd looks up.
Are you Dr. Louis Judd?
Yes.
I read your book. The one in which you wrote about the cure for drinking.
You're not a dipsomaniac at your age?
No. It's my father -- I wanted to talk to you -- you wrote about cures --
Judd silences her by raising his hand.
I'm sorry. I don't practice any more. I find it easier to write about mental illness and leave the cure of it to others.
The buzzer sounds and Miss Summers brings the phone recei to her ear.
(looking up from the phone) Mr. Ward is free now, Doctor.
Judd gets up and saunters toward the door.
(as he walks) There are any number of other psychiatrists who can help your father -- dipsomania is rather sordid.
He smiles charmingly at her, and deliberately pockets her lighter.
(as he goes through the door, disappointment in her voice) Thank you.
She reaches for a cigarette, then realizes that Judd has usurped her lighter. With a blank expression, she turns a looks at the closed door.
Dr. Judd comes in and walks calmly across the room.
(as he crosses) I've come from Jacqueline. She needs money.
I thought you told me you didn't know where she was.
(sprawling into) (a chair) I didn't. She came to me a few days ago. To put it delicately her care imposes a financial burden upon me. She thought you might lighten that burden.
If Jacqueline wants money she can come to me herself.
I'm afraid she can't do that, Ward. It would endanger her.
What sort of danger?
I'd like to tell you. I would tell you, but I'm fond of Jacqueline, I don't want her to run any risks.
This is nonsense! Unless I know where Jacqueline is, and how she is, I won't give you any money.
(almost musingly) You're a curious man. You're willing to jeopardize Jacqueline's life in order to satisfy your own curiosity.
You come to me with some wild story about her being in danger - naturally I want to know what kind of danger. I want to know where she is.
Gregory Ward rises and starts around the desk toward Dr. Judd.
It's not just for myself I'm asking. Her sister is here. The kid's half crazy with anxiety.
As a man, you distrust me В—- perhaps you believe me as a physician.
Judd looks coolly at Gregory and Gregory nods grudgingly.
Well, then I can tell you that in addition to other dangers, there is a grave danger of Jacqueline losing her sanity. I would advise against you seeing her.
But why? She's been ill --erratic, but I've never heard of anything like that!
I told you I was speaking as her physician -- not as anything else -- You can believe me or not, just as you choose.
Gregory looks at him a moment, then turns and sits down i his chair with an air of resignation.
(wearily) How much does she want?
She could use a hundred dollars.
(making a motion toward his desk) I'll give you a check.
(shaking his head) She can only use cash.
Ward takes out a billfold and examines its contents.
I haven't got that much in cash.
How much have you got?
About forty-five dollars.
For the time being, I imagine that must do.
Ward, frowning, hands over the money reluctantly.
Tell me, how is Jacqueline?
(rising) Oh, as beautiful as ever.
Judd starts for the door.
But tell me --
(shrugging) She's nervous, naturally, under the circumstances.
What circumstances?
Judd has reached the door. He turns and grins.
You know that I can't tell you.
He starts to open the door, pauses and looks back.
(insolently, with the door half open) As her physician and I am speaking as her friend now, too, I warn you that it would be extremely dangerous to attempt to see her.
The door closes behind Judd. Ward stands for a moment loo at the closed door, then crosses resolutely to a halltree the corner, takes his hat and coat and strides out.

It is the rest hour and the children are lying in a neat on the floor, each wrapped in his own little blanket. In middle of the row, one black-haired little girl keeps pok up her head to watch Mary and Gregory Ward. Ward, with hi overcoat on, and hat in hand, is seated on the corner of Mary's desk, his back to the children, talking to her. Ma sits at her desk watching.
What brought you down here, Greg?
(a little evasively) Oh, I had business with a man... but I missed him -В—
Well, I'm glad you came to see me.
The little girl in the center of the room sits up.
Can I wake up now, Miss Gibson?
You first have to go to sleep, Nancy. Then you can wake up. (to Gregory) We'll have to talk quietly.
Ward turns to look around the bright, sunny room.
Happy here?
Mary nods.
Everything has turned out so well for me - - I have a nice job -- friends - - except the one thing I came to New York for - -to find Jacqueline --
Gregory nods.

It's not knowing that makes it so hard. This way, whenever I walk along the streets I think I see her. I see some woman, peer into her face and find a stranger. I dream of her at night. It's terrible to say -- but if she were dead it would be easier. There would be some certainty about it.
Ward patiently pats her shoulder, and looks at her with understanding and sympathy. They face each other for a mo In the b.g. Nancy again rises from her neat fold of blank
Miss Gibson, I'm tired of resting.
Sh-h-h Nancy. The other children.
Nancy gives her a dirty look and subsides.
(turning) (back to Ward) What have you done about Irving August?
(a little guiltily) Oh, I'm making investigations.
You've never believed a word I told you about Mr. August.
Look, Mary, now that I know you better, I think I can be more frank with you. I don't believe you. I still can't understand the reason for such a wild tale. It's like some of Jacqueline's stories.
Greg, it isn't a wild tale. It's true. If there were only some way --
There is a very simple way. Got a telephone book?
Mary reaches into her desk drawer and pulls out the New Y telephone directory. He takes it and thumbs through it rapidly, then dials. While he is doing this, Nancy pokes her head again.
Is it fifteen minutes yet?
No, Nancy.        You've got to sleep two more minutes.
Nancy lets herself relax on the hard floor in quiet desperation. By this time Ward has finished dialing his number. Someone has evidently answered.
(into phone) May I speak to Mr. Irving August?
From the telephone comes the sound of unintelligible conversation in an explanatory note. Ward listens, frowni
(into phone) I'm very sorry. Thank you..
He hangs up the receiver and turns to Mary.
You were right. Irving August has been missing for three weeks.

Mary is saying good-bye to the children. They are being called for by their mothers. Most of the women are Italia Irish, Bohemian or Jewish New York women who collect thei offspring and move out with them through the little wicke gate. The children are carrying bits of childish craft wh they have manufactured during the day - paper baskets, crayola drawings. Each of the children shows off what he done during the day to his fond mama.
Mama, see. Miss Gibson helped me. It's a table.
Beautiful. We show it to papa tonight.
Did Michele eat her soup today?
She's been an angel.
A little boy comes running out of the building. He is the last and is late.
(yelling) Mama. Wait for me.
The drop seat of his little suit is hanging open. Mary ru after him.
Angelo. Wait.

She catches up with him, buttons his suit, gives him a playful pat on the bottom, and he runs after the others. turns to reВ—enter the nursery when Mrs. Wheeler comes ou Mrs. Wheeler is a middleВ—aged woman with a generous, ben smile on her face.
Well, Mary, aren't you the popular one. You've a visitor again.
Mary turns to walk toward the building with Mrs. Wheeler.
Mr. Ward?
No, not this time. It's a gentleman called Judd -- Dr. Judd.
I don't know anyone by that name.
He asked for you, my dear.
The two women go beck into the building.
Judd, wearing a dark overcoat and carrying his hat, is walking up and down. The door opens and Mary comes in.
Dr. Judd?
Yes, Miss Gibson. I've come to take you to your sister.
Mary stops, startled, and looks at him. He smiles.
Don't be so amazed. It's a very ordinary matter. I'm Jacqueline's physician... Mr. Ward told me you were in town and Jacqueline has sent me to bring you to her.
You know where she is?
(smiling even more broadly) If I didn't know where she was, could I take you to her? Get your hat and coat. We haven't much time.
He starts for the door, stumbles over a toy. Mary looks d at his feet. He catches the glance.
It's my cloven hoof. It trips me up sometimes.
Cloven hoof?
Yes. You know the devil and all his minions are marked that way.
Mary looks at him in astonishment as they exit through th door.

This is a marble, gilt, and plaster horror of the General Grant rococo period. Glass and gilt iron doors give entra to the hallway, which is floored with soiled marble slabs either side of the hall twin stairs rise to the apartment above, going upward with an accompaniment of gilt iron handrails. Some mail boxes, a worn velvet bench, and moth eaten moose head complete this charming and delicate interior. A young woman is laboriously getting a baby carriage out under one of the stairways and stowing her infant safely its wicker hold. She has tucked him In, steered the carri out from behind the stairway, and is crossing the hallway when the door opens to admit Judd and Mary.
(holding the door open for Mary) It's amid such marble splendors as these that Jacqueline dwells.
Mary looks around.
You can take either stairway -- I prefer the left В—- the sinister side.
They go toward the left and start ascending the left stairway.

head_text.subj: INT. HALLWAY IN FRONT OF JUDD'S APT- AFTERNOON

text: Mary and Judd come up the stairs. Judd is fumbling for a He goes to his door, inserts the key, twists it and swing the door open, allowing Mary to precede him.

It is a cheap, furnished apartment. An Aubusson carpet is the floor. The furniture is Grand Rapids Sheraton and the pictures on the wall are representative of hotel art at i worst, colored prints showing French canals, poplar trees old towers. An incongruous picture, however, a huge chrom an ornate fretwork frame dominates one wall. This is the famous picture of the guardian angel which shows a little child, gowned in white, who is about to fall over a preci wore it not for the benign hand of her guardian angel, a figure complete with white robe and white wings. Under th picture is a bureau. It has been converted to a writer's needs by the simple expedient of removing one drawer and reВ—inserting it so that the bottom of the drawer can be as a base for a typewriter. On this overturned drawer sta portable typewriter, a box full of paper, some loose manuscript and a marmalade jar full of pencils. Between a pair of bookends are about four volumes with the author's name В— Louis Judd В— plainly evident on the dust jackets are the only books in the room. At the end of the room is small, useless sort of desk. This has been made into a dressing table by putting a fitted toilet case on top and opening it. Through a double doorway, without doors, can seen a square cubicle containing an unmade bed. Mary come into this room and looks around anxiously. Judd follows h carefully bolts the door behind him and puts it on the ch
(calling softly) (toward bedroom) Jacqueline.
There is no answer and he strides across the room and loo in. He turns back to Mary.
(with genuine surprise) She's not here. She's gone.

Mary looks around her a little apprehensive at the though being alone with this stranger. However, his own nervousn at Jacqueline's absence is very genuine. As Mary crosses room to the desk he continues to talk excitedly.
I don't know why she left. She knows she shouldn't have.

Mary takes a hand mirror out of the fitted case and holds up. A big swirling monogram on the back is immediately visible. The letters are: "J. G." Mary puts it down. In a little ash tray beside the dressing case a cigarette is smoldering. Mary points to it. Judd looks at it, then qui crosses the room to a door obviously leading to a bathroo He knocks, and receiving no answer, opens it and turns ba to the room.
She's gone. She's left me to meet them alone. I can't.
Mary stands looking at him, amazed at this sudden transit the almost palpable fear of this smooth, easy, sneering m
(softly) What makes you so nervous, Dr. Judd. Who are they?
Judd pays no attention to her. He walks quickly to the ot end of the room, then turns to face her.
I can't stay here. I'll have to leave you.

Without any further word he strides quickly to the entran door, fumbles furiously with the chain and lock; opens it goes out, closing the door behind him. Mary stands in the center of the room, completely at a lo She turns back to the desk and snuffs out the cigarette thoughtfully. Again she examines the mirror or some other article in the dressing case, As she stands there, lookin her sister's initials, there is a soft knock at the door. Mary crosses the room quickly and opens it.

MED. CLOSE SHOT - Jacqueline Gibson, dressed for the stre in a mink coat and a smart fur toque to match; an impress beautiful, unforgettable woman, stands in this mean hallw TWO SHOT - Mary and Jacqueline in doorway.
(from doorway) Jacqueline!

Jacqueline lifts her hand and puts her forefinger stealth across her lips to indicate silence. They stand facing ea other this way for a single, breathing moment. Then sudde Jacqueline pulls the door shut.
CLOSE SHOT of Mary, surprised and shocked by this sudden move, stands stockВ—still for half a second. Then she rou herself. She starts tugging at the door. She gets it open starts out.

Mary comes out into the hall, looks first toward the left stairway. There is no one there. REVERSE SHOT. Apparently Mary looks to the right and agai sees that the hallway and the head of the second flight o stairs is empty. She hesitates for a moment and then star off to the right.
Mary runs down the stairs.
Mary comes down the stairs. The foyer is empty. She cross to the other stairs and looks up, sees no one, turns and out the street door.

Mary comes out and looks up and down the street. The stre is empty except for a few men passing by. She stands for moment, the wind blowing her skirt against her legs and tugging at her hair. She turns and goes back into the building.
Mary comes in and starts to mount the stairs.

location: HALLWAY IN FRONT OF JUDD' S AFT. LATE AFTERNO

text: Mary comes up to the hallway. The door of the apartment i still open. She turns and enters.

Mary reВ—enters the room. She goes over to the dressing t where she had left her purse and picks it up. As she does this something in the mirror attracts her attention, and look of terror comes into her face. In the mirror can be the back of a large chair near the bureau. Over the top o this chair floats a rising column of cigar smoke. Mary tu ANOTHER ANGLE. A man enters from the left of the scene an seizes Nary's arm. From the armchair another man rises. I Paul Radeau, the man with Irving August at the Missing Persons Bureau.
(to Radeau) Is this her?
Nope. (turning to Mary, removing his cigar from his mouth) Where's Jacqueline Gibson?
(frightened) I don't know.
She was just here. Where's she gone?
I tell you I don't know.
That's funny. You went out with her, came back alone, and don't know where she went.
I don't know.
There is a pause while Radeau studies her and Mary's cour comes back to her.
Why do you want Jacqueline? What right have you to question me?
Radeau pulls an official looking document from his pocket
Young lady, I've got all the right in the world. I'm Paul Radeau, private investigator, and I have been hired to find your sister by her husband, Gregory Ward.
CLOSEUP of Mary's face as the full realization of what he said comes to her.
(almost in a whisper) Husband --

The restaurant is full, cheerful and noisy with the merry sound of people eating, drinking and talking. MED. CLOSE SHOT of Jason Hoag seated at the feet of Dante small quarto volume is opened at his left hand and he is reading as he eats his antipasto. Without looking he take the last forkful from the plate scrabbles about with his for another forkful but finds only emptiness, and he turn his attention from his book to his plate. He puts down hi fork and looks off beyond the camera, calling out at the time.
(in Italian) What ho, wench! Would you keep a benighted traveller waiting?

REVERSE SHOT - kitchen door. Mrs. Romari, a beaming smile her face, comes from the kitchen bearing an enormous plat of spaghetti. She weaves her way through the tables, hold the platter high over the heads of the customers. She pas a table at which Mary is seated with Gregory Ward. As it wall table, they sit side by side. Both look miserable, t faces averted, Gregory is talking eagerly to Mary's turnedВ—away profile. Mrs. Romari passes them and advance toward the table where Jason sits. MED. CLOSE SHOT - Jason at his table. Mrs. Romari the scene beaming, puts the platter on the        table b Jason.
(in Italian) Jason, my pet В—В—

Bella Romari        If I were not seated, I would embrace you in three movements like a sonata. (in very bad Italian) Ah, my wonderful one. Fly with me tonight. We will take your coffee machine and live with the gypsies.
Mrs. Romari giggles with delight and translates Jason's atrocious Italian to two maiden ladies who are gawking at this unrestrained conversation.
(in Italian) Oh, this funny man. (in English) He is a very funny man, but I love him.
While she is talking, Jason has been appreciatively sniff the aroma of the spaghetti. As she turns back to him, he points to his wine glass.
What are you thinking of, Bella? Can I eat dry?
Oh, the wine. I have forgotten the wine.
Mrs. Romari goes toward the kitchen. The CAMERA DOLLIES WITH her. As she passes the table wher Gregory and Mary are sitting, the CAMERA STOPS, FOCUSING them.
Look, Mary, just because I kept a secret from you doesn't make me a monster. Please look at me, Mary.
Mary pays no attention, but busies herself by taking a si water and pretends to be very interested in Mrs. Romari's further progress through the dining room.
Can't I make you understand? The secret wasn't mine in the first place. It was Jacqueline's. I don't know why. She never wanted anything from me -- not even my name В—В—
Mary still looks obstinately away. Gregory shakes his hea pauses, and then goes on.
Please В—- I can't explain things like this to your right ear.
Last night in this very restaurant Mr. Jason Hoag paid a very pretty compliment to my right ear.
(exasperated) Who the devil is he?
A poet. He's sitting right over there. That's his table В—В— the one at the feet of Dante.
She half turns to indicate Jason's position. MED. CLOSE SHOT of Jason. He sees Mary looking toward him smiles and nods to her. MED. CLOSE SHOT of Mary and Gregory. Mary nods back to Ja

(looking off at Jason) He seems all right. (then resuming his former conversation) Look, Mary. It was something I couldn't tell you. Remember how you came to my office that first day, frightened and broken up? I asked you if she had spoken about me. You said "no." Then how could I tell you that we were married -- and afterwards -- I couldn't tell you because --

Mrs. Romari comes past them.. She is carrying a bottle of Chianti. She smiles at Mary as she passes, but Mary is to absorbed in her own thoughts to see her. The CAMERA DOLLIES WITH Mrs. Romari. MED. CLOSE SHOT of Jason. Mrs. Romari comes into the scen and starts pouring a glass of wine.
(in bad Italian) Why do you bring me wine, beautiful ones when you yourself are intoxicating.
Mrs  Romari laughs heartily.
(in English) You're my favorite audience, Bella.

Mrs. Romari has finished pouring the wine. She puts the w bottle on the table and is about to start off toward the kitchen when she catches a glimpse of Gregory and Mary. Mary's face is still averted from Gregory and both of the look dreadfully unhappy. MED. SHOT of Jason and Mrs. Romari.

Why can't everyone be happy like we are -- laugh and have good times. Look at that poor little one В— so sad because she can't find her sister. And that man with her -В— he doesn't make her laugh В—В— he just sits and talks.
(almost seriously) We are happy, Mrs. Romari, because you have everything В—В— and I am happy because I have nothing to lose.
But you should make her laugh, Jason. Come, make jokes for her. I'll bring your food to their table.
Before Jason can protest she has leaned over and taken hi plate. MED. SHOT - Mary and Gregory. Their relative positions ha not changed.
You could have told me any time you were Jacqueline's husband.
Things changed, Mary. The reasons for finding Jacqueline changed. I want to find Jacqueline to settle things.
(startled, turns for the first time to Ward) What things? Why?
It is at this moment and before he can answer that Mrs. Romari comes into the scene leading Jason.
You two are so sad. Your food will not digest, and your wine will sour. You must laugh to eat well. I have brought Jason to make you laugh.
Mary looks at Ward. He is obviously annoyed at this interruption. She, too, wishes that Mrs. Romari and Jason not interrupted, but feels it incumbent upon her to be gracious.
Mr. Hoag, this is Mr. Ward.

The two men shake hands. Ward with the air of one making empty invitation, hoping that Jason will not accept, indicates the char on the opposite side of the table. Jason stands smiling for a moment, completely aware of th situation and uncertain as to whether to accept or take himself off. Mrs. Romari settles the matter by pulling ou the chair and forcing him to seat himself.
Sit down. I'll get the rest of your dinner.

I'm under orders to make you laugh. In Mrs. Romari's mind my poetry and humor have some strange affinity which they don't have in fact. She wants me to play the fool for you, and suddenly, Miss Gibson, I feel as sad as you do.
(smiling) Well,then I have spoiled your dinner -- "your food won't digest, and your wine will sour."
You will have to make all the jokes, because I'm going to be very serious.
He pauses, and the two look rather questioningly at him a this preamble. He looks first at one and then at the othe before speaking.
I'm going to find your sister.
I don't think that's a good subject for jokes, Mr. Hoag.
But I'm not joking.
Don't be ridiculous. For months I've had the best private detective in New York looking for Miss Gibson.
But I'm better than a detective. I have an understanding of people - and a love of them -- an understanding of the city - -
You don't even know Jacqueline Gibson.
But I understand her. That may be more important.
It may make very fine poetry, Mr. Hoag, but it doesn't make good sense.
Jason turns to Mary.
Mary, when you first came here, I told you to look into your heart. You didn't listen to me. You listened to the policeman instead. You didn't find your sister, did you?
(protesting) Look here, just because Mrs. Romari asked you to amuse us.
Jason rises and takes Mary's hand.
This city is my world. I know every rat-infested corner of my world and every starlit chamber of its purity and greatness.
He half draws Mary to her feet.
You don't even know where to start - -
Jason takes Mary along with him, starting for the door.
One starts by beginning. Beginnings lead to an end.
Ward is forced to rise and go with them.

Jason and Ward with Mary between them, cross the street toward the north side of Washington Mews. To their right the mews, the little houses one next to the other in an orderly row. They stop for a moment at the street corner.
Well?

(disregarding his question) This is the part of New York I love. It is old. It has memories. If you listen, the houses will speak to you. Walt Whitman...Edna St. Vincent Millay... Eugene O'Neill...in their time they've all lived here.
He goes on to the next house and they follow. The CAMERA DOLLIES WITH them.
All very nice but, what are you going to do - listen at every house in New York for Jacqueline's voice?
(as if it explained everything) I'm looking for a party -- a merry party.
Well, that's illuminating.
Even Mary looks concerned and puzzled. They have stopped before the next house and again Jason has taken the attit of one listening. The sound of a violin can be heard play Abenlied.
Only music. It leads, but we cannot follow.
He starts off again. Ward and Mary follow him.
(shaking his head) Riddles now.
By this time they have come to the third house and again Jason has paused.
Wait. This is a party.
(from interior of house) Now, if you'll all take your seats, Miss Randall will show us the slides she took of Woods Hole Marine Institute this summer.
Sounds dull, doesn't it? My ear is perfectly trained. I can tell the brand of liquor and the quality of the guests from the noise they make.
From the next house comes the sound of revelry, laughter a burst of jazz music from a phonograph which obscures th milder noises of the house in front of which they stand.
(excitedly) That sounds more like it. Come on.
He grabs hold of Mary's hand and draws her along. They go to the door. Ward follows them.

CLOSE SHOT of Natalie Cortez. She is seated at a small ca table, shuffling a pack of cards with one hand, and surrounded by a small group of her guests in evening clot Natalie is a very beautiful woman of early middle age. It apparent why she uses only one hand to shuffle her cards. has but one arm. A        little cape of gold lame covers shoulders and hangs down over the missing arm.
Shuffle the cards well, Natalie. This is a trick of telepathy not card manipulation
ANOTHER SHOT of the same group to include Judd, who stand little distance away with his back purposely turned to th card table. Mrs. Cortez is finishing shuffling the cards. door knocker sounds.
Now pass me the cards.
The knocker sounds again and Mrs. Cortez hands the cards Gladys, a big, gushy girl, full of hormones and cocktail
(rising) Gladys, you hand the deck to Louis while I answer the door.

Gladys takes the cards and crosses to Judd, who still sta with his back to his audience, while Mrs. Cortez turns an walks in the other direction. REVERSE SHOT - toward the door. For the first time Mrs. Cortez' living quarters can be seen. The house was former stable on the Mews and in remodeling it for living purpos Mrs. Cortez has allowed the stalls and general architectu of the stable to remain. She uses one of the two stalls a little dining nook, although above it the name of the hor "Apocalypse" is still printed on a placard. The next stal has been converted into a little escritoire, and over thi stall is the name "Morning Star." The place is lit with electrified stable and carriage lamps and furnished with harness and horse adornments which contrast with the rich piled carpet, the lovely square piano of rosewood and the beautiful modern prints with plain wood frames. Book shel cover the largest portion of the walls. Mrs. Cortez wends her way through little groups of her gu and goes to the door. MED. CLOSE SHOT of the door as Mrs. Cortez opens it revea Mary, Ward and Jason on the threshold.
Jason! How nice to see you.
(taking her hand) I have brought some friends, Natalie. May we all come to your party?
Of course.
Mrs,. Cortez, Mary Gibson and Mr. Ward.
(to Mary) It's so nice to meet you.
Jason has been looking about trying to peer over the head various other guests. Suddenly he turns back to Mrs. Cort and Mary.
You'll have to excuse me.
ANOTHER ANGLE - Jason emerges between two groups of peopl The CAMERA PICKS him up and DOLLIES WITH him up to the gr around Judd. Judd has turned and is facing them with the cards in his hands.
Mrs. Freeman, yours was the Jack of Spades. Gladys, yours was the Seven of Diamonds, and Mrs. Gosden, the Queen of Hearts -В—
There is a murmur of admiration from the little group.
How do you ever do it, Louis?
Jason makes his way through the group and faces Judd.
Hello, Jason.
Jason takes his arm and draws him away a few feet from th group.
(sotto voce) Where is Jacqueline Gibson?
(smiling) What a peculiar question.
I saw you with her last week. I knew you'd be here tonight. Where is she?
My dear fellow, it's neither your business to ask, nor mine to tell.
He tries to move away. Jason takes his arm again.
Wait. Look over there.
He half turns so that Judd faces the door.
See that girl? That's Jacqueline's sister. It's because of her I ask.
But why come to me?
Because there was another girlВ— years ago -- a nice girl. She lived on Barrow Street. I saw her with you once -В— I saw her with you twice and then I never saw her again. That's why.
She was my patient.
He pauses.
What was she to you?
I don't think that you would understand if I told you.
I think I understand without your telling me. I know something of your history, Jason. I know that you haven't written for ten years.
I've lost my knack.
After that wonderful first book В—- after all the adulation and the good reviews?
Jason looks away.
I would have given anything if I could have written that book. You had all my admiration and respect В— once.
MED. SHOT - Mary, Mrs. Cortez and Ward.
Now that you know me, you must feel free to come often.

Over this shot comes the sound of Jason's voice calling M Mary smiles at Mrs. Cortez and looks off. LONG SHOT from Mary's ANGLE of the group around Judd and Jason. Jason is beckoning to her. THREE SHOT - Mary, Mrs. Cortez and Ward. Mary gives Mrs. Cortez a smile of apology and starts toward Jason. Ward t her arm to lead her through the party throng. MED. CLOSE SHOT - the group around Jason and Judd as Mary Ward come in.
(imperturbably) Hello, Ward.
He makes a half bow to Mary.
My dear Miss Gibson --
It is at this point that Gladys comes bursting back. She picks up the name "Gibson" and rushes ever to Mary.
Gibson? Are you Jacqueline's sister?
Yes. Do you --
(not letting her finish) Know her! My dear, we were intimate! The times we used to have together! I bet she never told you about that -- you're too young.
I'm afraid you don't understand. Miss Gibson's sister is missing В—В—
Missing? Well, no wonder. When she took up with Louis Judd she went out of circulation, like that!
She snaps her fingers. Mary looks from Judd to Ward. The two men stare fixedly at each other.
(to Mary) My dear, have I said something?
(to Gladys in a low voice) No. You've just turned the dagger in the wound - - a beautiful job.

He looks quickly over to Mary, sees tears coming to her e takes her elbow and leads her to another part of the room Gladys' attention is attracted by laughter from another g of the party and she drifts off. Ward and Judd are left together.
(to Ward) There are too many people here. I think Jacqueline may be lonely --? for me.
Judd grins. He wanders off. Gregory stands scowling after him. TWO SHOT - Jason and Mary. They have seated themselves in little breakfast nook built in the horses' stall.
You see, Mary, I'm not quite a fool.
Mary nods.
At least you knew about Dr. Judd.
Yes.
And you knew he'd be here.
Yes. And now that I've shown you that I know that much, and can guess more -- will you trust me to look for Jacqueline?
I want you to look for Jacqueline.
He takes her hand across the table and holds it firmly.
I'm a terrible failure, Mary, -- a book clerk by day and a poet by night, and not a very good one - but if you'll trust me -- at this one thing I won't fail --I'll find your sister.
CLOSE SHOT of Jason leaning on a file counter in the libr Beside him is an enormous file of cards and right under h nose, two pretty white hands ruffle the cards.
(admiringly) You have such lovely hands, Miss Gottschalk. So slim and capable --
The CAMERA PULLS BACK to show us Miss Gottschalk. The fac doesn't match the hands.
(gurgling) Oh, Mr. Jason. I really shouldn't be doing this, you know. It's against the rules. (curiously) When did you say you wanted them?
I want to see what they read so I'll know what kind of books to give my friends as presents. There's nothing nicer for a gift than a book.
Who was the first one -- Mrs. Redi?
Jason nods.
(ruffling through the cards) N - o - p - q - r - r - Redi. Here it is.
She takes the card out of the file and hands it to Jason.
And the other was Judd?
Yes, Dr. Louis Judd.
It's here, too.
She hands it over to Jason.
Would it be asking too much, Miss Gottschalk, for you to get me these books?
(gurgling again) No, not at all, Mr. Jason.
She takes the cards and glances at the numbers and stops.
(coyly) Why, Mr. Jason. Most of these books are on the closed shelf. You have to get permission.
(using Miss Gottschalk's tone) I wouldn't want to take them out. I just want to look at them.
(relenting) Well, since, you're over twenty oneВ—В—
Giggling, she turns to go.

Jason comes up the stairs whistling. As he reaches the landing, Mimi comes out of her door at the end of the corridor and goes across to the bathroom. She is in her soiled dressing gown, her hair lank about her shoulders. carries a towel over one arm.
(waving to her) Mimi!

She turns toward him and is about to speak when a fit of coughing takes her. She passes on, goes through the doorw to the bath. Jason goes on to a door halfway down the hal #lO. He knocks on the door. Mary's voice can be heard bid him enter.
Come in.

Jason turns the knob and throws the door open. Through th open door Mary's room can be seen. It is a small, dismal cubicle like the room with the noose. There is a day bed, dresser, a little desk, an armchair, an oldВ— fashioned r and light curtains at the window. There are a few oddВ—sh pillows on the day bed and some other evidences of Mary's attempts to make this place bright and livable. On the dresser top stands a large framed photograph of Jacquelin As the door opens, Mary can be seen washing a pair of whi gloves in a little basin set in the corner of the room. As the scene progresses,, she can be seen washing the glo on her hands, removing them, rinsing out the soap and the tacking them up on the open window sash to dry. Jason pul rose from his pocket. A withered blossom. He offers it. M holds up her white-gloved hands to indicate that she can' take the flower. He picks up a tumbler, fills it with wat puts the rose in it, and sets the whole mess on the windo sill.
It's terribly sweet of you, Jason.
I have something even better.
He fishes through his pockets and brings out a ragged wor piece of paper; crossing over to her he carefully smooths this paper beside the wash basin.
(puzzled) What is it?
INSERT        THE PARALLELOGRAM traced on thin paper.
A parallelogram with a split triangle in its very center.
But for what, Jason?
To unlock mysteries -- to unravel the thread that leads to Jacqueline.
Mary looks helpless and bewildered.
(with mock patience) I suppose I'll have to explain. Go on with your washing.
He seats himself on the edge of the day bed.
I have been at the library.
But you're always at the library.
I went as a detective. I found out that Mrs. Redi reads the same books as Dr. Judd.
I don't think that's so revealing.
But who is Judd, a psychiatrist. It's quite natural that he should read books on the history of old religious societies. But why should Mrs. Redi, a woman with a beauty parlor --?
I don't know.
That's it. And this figure --she traced it. The book I saw at the library had been marked "perfect" by the library inspector in March. Mrs. Redi had it out in April. No one else had read it since.
(laughing) I'm at sea, Jason.
(with even more patience) Such a simple matter. This figure is the symbol of the Palladists.
(lightly mocking) It's all clear to me now -- so clear.
I thought it would be, but just to be sure, I'll tell you that the Palladists are a society of Devil worshippers --
Devil worshippers!
She bursts out laughing.
Look. I'm serious. It's a real and vary earnest society -- a dangerous society...
(still laughing) I can imagine.
Some time before those nice white gloves are dry you're going to go and find out a few things about Mrs. Redi.

Mary chuckles to herself and, taking up one of the gloves blows into it, laughing in spite of herself as she does s In a playful mood, she brushes the blown-up glove against back of Jason's neck. He starts nervously. Like a young child, Mary is thrown into a fit of laughter.
Oh, Jason, I scared you. Maybe I could scare some information out of Mrs. Redi or perhaps Frances.
She laughs gaily.

head_text.subj: BOOTH AT LA JEUNESSE COSMETICS, INC.

text: This is a mirror shot. In the glass Mary can be seen seat in the chair with Frances Fallon behind her brushing her hair.
I can't see much fun in teaching school. Why don't you go into the beauty business.
But I like teaching school.
Well, if it's fun for you, it's all right. I get a kick out of my work when the customers aren't too crabby.
Is Mrs. Redi nice to work for?
Redi's all right.
She seems rather an odd woman to me.
She's a pretty good sort.
What does she do with herself after business hours?
Frances shrugs.
It always seemed to me she was sort of lonely and unhappy.
I guess most people are.
Frances finishes brushing her hair and pats it into place
Well, that's it.
While Mary gets up and collects her handbag and other belongings, Frances makes out the check and hands it to M
In the old days, it would have been on the house.
Mary hands her a coin which Frances refuses, pushing her away.
The tip is, anyhow. I like to work on your hair.
Thank you.
Mary takes a piece of paper from her bag and shows it to Frances.
Do you know what this is, Frances?
(smiling broadly) I ought to know.
What is it?
Frances reaches back of her, takes a bottle of La Jeuness perfume and holds it up to Mary. INSERT        BOTTLE OF LA JEUNESSE PERFUME. On the front the parallelogram with split triangle.
(over shot) It's Mrs. Redi's new trademark.
Of course, I should have known. That figure has been puzzling me.
