She passes into the main portion of the salon and Frances follows her. Mrs. Redi, passing by, stops.
Hello, Mary. It's nice to see you. No news of Jacqueline?
Mary shakes her head.
I'm afraid not.
That's too bad.
Mary goes on toward the cashier's desk, and pays her chec As Mrs. Redi and Frances stand talking, Mary gets her cha and leaves in the background.
What did she want?
I did her hair.
What were you talking about?
Nothing.
Nothing! That's absurd. I heard you laughing and talking, She was asking questions.
She was just asking about you - Whether it was nice to work for you or not.
And that was all?
No. She asked about the trademark.
What did she want to know?
She showed me a drawing.
(in anger) You        fool! That symbol is us -- us. She was asking about us.
She looks off toward the door opening on the street.
But I'll stop her questions В—В—

Judd, dressed in a dressing gown, is seated on the straig chair before the makeshift desk, talking with Mrs. Cortez is dressed in street clothes and who has perched herself the arm of a large, overstuffed chair. They have evidentl been talking for some time. The scene opens with a slight lull in the conversation, while Judd takes a cigarette an lights it, blows out the first inhalation of smoke and lo squarely at Mrs. Cortez.
I know the others -- Redi, Fallon, Leo, Bruns. But I would never have guessed it of you, Natalie.
(airily) One believes -В— it's like any other religion...
I'd hardly describe It that way В—- The worship of evil is a pretty dreadful and special thing.
It seems right to us.

I know the theory behind the movement. If one believes in good one believes in evil. If one believes in God, one must believe in the devil. And an intelligent person can make his own choice В—В— that's it, isn't it?
Because you are intelligent -- that's why they sent me to you --
I think I can give you a more practical reason for your kind invitation. I know too much. I was Jacqueline's psycho-analyst.
I always thought it was a more intimate relationship.
Judd shrugs.
Perhaps, Natalie, this is a bargain you're offering me --I am being allowed to join -- to buy safety by betraying Jacqueline -- is that it?
I haven't said anything of the sort.
But you would like to know where she is?
Yes. There are certain punitive measures...
I can imagine. But you did say you came to me as my friend --that you were concerned for me.
Natalie nods.
I'm afraid you have mistaken my motive, Louis. I thought you might understand and sympathize.
I have no sympathy for either good or evil. I have only curiosity -- a professional curiosity. What unhappy people most of you are!
Are we?        I thought I was very gay.

A gay lot -В— Redi, for instance.  I don't know what her sorrow is,        but her life's an empty one. She's had to have this to cling to. Frances Fallon, with her worship of Jacqueline, has had to follow like a sheep. And Bruns, the fanatic. And you...
He looks at her empty sleeve. She looks down, and her mou twists in a smile.
I was a great dancer...
A strange collection. You're like the false god you worship... fallen angels, all of you.
Life has betrayed us. We've found there is no heaven on earth, so we must worship evil for evil's own sake. We're not wicked. We commit no violence, unless...
(smiling, close to her) Unless what?

(a pause, then smiling, sure of herself) No, you draw no secrets from me, as you drew them from Jacqueline. You are not one of us yet. You're clever, Louis, but I recognize your interest in me for what it is worth. You are only curious. You have never loved a woman who had but one arm.
It would be a charming experience. She might only protest half as much.
(rising) You're very flippant and perhaps wise, but not wise enough to see the truth, Louis.
Judd walks with Mrs. Cortez to the door.
(very sincerely) What is truth?
Mrs. Cortez looks at him from the doorway in surprise.
Those are the first words I have ever heard you say without mockery and contempt.
Judd smiles.
Mrs. Romari, with the pigeon on the table in front of her shelling beans. As she shells them she sings an Italian s her voice ringing out merrily.

Mary is in the shower. It is an old-fashioned affair with a round pipe rail above it from which a translucent curtain is hanging to keep the water from splashing. Mary head, neck, shoulders and a portion of her back can be se She is wearing a shower cap. The warm water is streaming her, making a comfortable fog of steam. Mary is humming o whistling the song that Mrs. Romari was singing downstair She lifts her hand to soap the back of her neck. A dark a threatening shadow falls athwart the curtain, and through steam and water a figure can be dimly seen standing there is a moment or two before this figure speaks.
Mary.
Mary looks toward the shower curtain and sees the grim indeterminate bulk of someone standing there. She brings hands and arms up protectively huddling all her forces together in embarrassment.
(her voice weak and embarrassed) Yes.
This is Mrs. Redi, Mary.
(reaching for the faucet) I'll be out in a minute.
That won't be necessary. I haven't much to say.
Mary turns the water off and stands listening.
If I were you, Mary -- I'd go back to school. I'd make no further attempt to find Jacqueline.
Why?
It will make you unhappy to find Jacqueline. It would put her in danger --- great danger --
There is a little silence.
I can almost feel your doubt about what I'm saying, Mary.
I can't give up looking for her, Mrs. Redi, no matter what you're hinting at.
I have no intention whatsoever of hinting. Your sister, Mary, is a murderess. She killed Irving August -- stabbed him out of fright when he discovered where she was hiding.
I don't believe it.

I had to help get rid of the body. You saw it on the subway. And I warn you, Mary -- go back -- you don't know what you're doing, or what dreadful things you might bring about by looking for your sister. You go back to school - - go back and forget Jacqueline.

The shadow of Mrs. Redi's figure leaves the curtain. The clicks shut behind her. Mary moves her hand out to part t curtain. CLOSE UP of Mary's face as seen from the other side of th shower curtain as she opens it. She is looking off at the door through which Mrs. Redi has passed.

LONG SHOT  There is a fire burning in the fireplace. The lamps have been lit, although outdoors there is still a g cold light in the street. The room looks bright and warm. There are about a dozen people who are        standing an smoking and chatting. Before the sofa a tea service has b set on the coffee table. An alcohol stove keeps the tea w hot and a slight steam rises from the tea kettle. Among the guests can be seen certain familiar faces. Fran Fallon stands near the door talking with a young man, Mr. Durk, who can be recognized as one of the two drunks who supported the body of Irving August on the subway. The ot of the two drunks, Mr. Leo, is seated by himself in an armchair looking through a record album. In his street clothes, chatting with a very lovely, white-haired woman, Joseph, the workman at La Jeunesse. Mrs. Cortez is opening the door, as the scene opens, to a Mrs. Redi, who is dressed in exactly the same clothes she wore in the previous scene.
(starting to remove her furs) I'm sorry to be late, Natalie.
(taking the furs and hanging them over the back of a chair) We haven't even begun tea yet.
The two women cross to the sofa and sit down. On the way across the room, Mrs. Redi nods to several of the people standing about. She and Mrs. Cortez seat themselves.
Won't you pour, Mrs. Redi?
Mrs. Redi pours out a cup of tea. Her hand trembles and s moves rather awkwardly.
Sorry. I'm nervous. This is very trying for me.
I know. You introduced Jacqueline to us -- but how could you tell В—-
I should have known. She had no sincerity В—- no real belief.
Mrs. Cortez pats Mrs. Redi's hand comfortingly, then turn and calls out,
Cream or lemon, Frances?
Lemon.

Frances comes forward and Mr. Durk comes with her. They s beside the sofa near Mrs. Redi. Mrs. Redi pours another c of tea. Mrs. Cortez poises the cream pitcher over it. She turns to a tall dark-haired woman who is standing near th window.
Miss Rowan, do you take cream?

Miss Rowan, without bothering to answer, strides across t room and takes the teacup from her hand. She seats hersel a small chair facing the sofa. Mrs. Redi starts to pour another cup of tea, but has a slight mishap. There is a clatter.
Please, Natalie, would you mind pouring?
Mrs. Cortez takes the teapot in her hand and begins pouri
You shouldn't be nervous. There is nothing personal or vengeful in what we are about to do. We have only to make a decision.
A tall quiet woman has come up to the table. She speaks  to Mrs. Cortez.
But it can be such a horrible decision. I found peace here. I know that a large portion of that peace came because we are all pledged to non-violence. Now this --
Our founder must have known when he wrote these seemingly contradictory rules -В— the rule of non-violence and the law that whoever betrays us must die -- he must have known.
But I can't understand it.
Mrs. Redi turns to her.
Some of us, Frances, must believe without understanding.
Yes.
As she speaks, a mature, handsome, forceful man dressed i dark business suit, Mr. Bruns, comes forward.
I went back through the history last night. I read about Johann Rozenquartz -- I read what he  wrote --
I can quote it fully, Mrs. Redi. "We will avoid violence. For once undertaken, violence becomes its own master and can lead to either good or evil."
But he also wrote --

(interrupting) I can quote that too; "Those who shall go out into the market place and let their tongues speak of us, and give knowledge of our being and our deeds, whom-so-ever doeth this shall die."
Since the founding of our order there have been six betrayals and six deaths. And now there is Jacqueline В—В— she is the seventh.
You can't do anything to her-- you mustn't hurt her!
But she betrayed us, Frances.
She never betrayed us. She was only going to a doctor -- a psychiatrist.
But she told him, Frances. She told him about us.
(to Frances) I know this is difficult for you. I know that you love her.
She didn't betray us!

Even if I believed that, I would still consider her dangerous. There is the matter of Irving August's death. Without consulting me, Mrs. Redi was illВ—advised enough to have the body removed by Leo and Durk. This makes us all a party to the crime. What if there is a trial? What if Jacqueline is asked how the body was removed? Do you think, Frances, she would keep silent?
There is a long pause. He looks around the circle.
It is a very real danger and one which forces our decision.
What about Judd -- he knows about us.
He will come to us of himself В—В— the man is evil.
And Jacqueline's sister?
I have taken care of Mary. I've spoken to her. She's going back to school.
Then it is decided. Leo and Durk and I will make our plans.
Frances Fallen begins to cry. Outside the streetlights go

Ahead of her, a slim figure, not unlike Leo's, is walking up the street toward her. She dodges into the next alley. This is an alley behind a theatre. It is cluttered with all sorts of strange impedimenta; flats, crates, etc. There is an overhead lam burning in the center of the alley, but the periphery of light beneath it, does not extend to the walls of the all The area immediately adjacent to these walls is heavy wit darkness and strange shadows. Jacqueline stands in the mi of the pool of light and listens. It seems to her that sh can hear in the darkness the soft tap-tap of someone walk on his toes. She shrinks back from the bright light into darkness and begins to grope her way along the wall, She going from left to right. A sound at her right attracts h attention and she looks off, but continues to grope her w along the wall to the left. Her hand passes from the roughness of the wall to the smoothness of cloth and a sp second later, Leo, whom she has touched, grins as he seiz her wrist. She screams and then silently struggles to fre herself. Still smiling he holds her firmly with his right band. With his left hand he draws something from his pock He presses a button on this and a four-and a-half inch kn blade flashes out. Jacqueline stands stock still with fri Leo's hand goes back for the blow. At the opposite side of the alley a door is suddenly thro wide open and a great patch of light is thrown on Jacquel and Leo. He puts the knife behind his back. Out of the door come half a dozen people in costumes. The are members of a ballet company performing in the theatre Also there emerges the sound of loud and merry music. The actors are in a gay mood laughing and shouting. One o them breaks into a half dance step. It is infectious and rest join in, making a sort of Carmagnole that sweeps dow the alley. Jacqueline breaks from Leo's hand-hold on her wrist and runs in among them. One of the dancers is an enormous man dressed in Roman ha armor to represent the god Gambrinus, with gilded hop blo as a garland about his shoulders and wearing a papier mac mask, surmounted by crown of similarly gilded hop leaves wheat. The face of the mask is a grinning, jolly, rubicun visage.  It is next to this enormous man that Jacqueline finds herself. In sportive mood the giant dancer sweeps h up with one arm, forcing her to dance his grotesque steps
Please. Please. Let me down. There's a man following me.
(in a booming voice) I shouldn't wonder, Babe. I shouldn't wonder.
I'm serious В—В— help me.
I'll help you to a beer and a sandwich. Come along, babe, come along.
The whole party of dancers with Jacqueline among them, go roaring out of the alley.

On the street corner is a beer saloon. The dancers, some them still skipping and dancing, come around and go into brilliantly lit saloon. The dancer with Jacqueline tries pull her into the saloon. She fights away from him. Laugh and slapping his thigh in mirth, he leaves her and passes into the saloon. She is left alone in the street. She mak halfВ—hearted movement to adjust her disarranged clothing Slowly, with great weariness, she begins to walk away fro the saloon, going further and further into the darkness. looks around. The darkness frightens her. She looks back. There is the warm glow of light from the saloon windows. starts to go back. From the lighted end of the street a m crosses to the same side of the street as Jacqueline. His silhouette somewhat resembles the silhouette of Leo. She turns, runs and is lost in the darkness.
The Palladists, with the exception of Leo, are all here a all seated. Judd, still wearing his overcoat, is seated i small chair facing them and beside him stands Jason.
Now that you've hounded and worried her half to death, you don't oven know where she is. At least tell me, has she been here?
She was here for a little while.
And what happened?
Nothing. She left here an hour or so ago. She may even be home now. Why don't you try it?
All right, Jason.
Judd gets up and they start for the door. Half-way to the door, Jason stops and turns around. Judd also turns.
(looking around the room and peering at each person in turn) The devil worshipers -- the lovers off evil. It's a joke-В—a pathetic little joke.
We've not asked your opinion.
I propose to give it to you anyway. You're a poor, wretched group of people who have taken the wrong turning.
Wrong? Who knows what is right or wrong?

I can prove you wrong so simply Listen: (he bows his head and recites very quietly) Our father who art in heaven Hallowed be thy name Thy kingdom come, thy will be done On earth as it is in heaven. Give us this day, our daily bread Forgive us our trespasses as we Forgive those who trespass against us. Lead us not into temptation But deliver us from evil For thine is the kingdom, the power And the glory forever. Amen.

As he prays, the CAMERA MOVES FROM one off the Palladists another. Tears form in Frances Fallon's eyes. Mrs. Redi t her head. Even Bruns, the ardent and fanatical believer, chokes back a sob. Both men turn and go. The CAMERA HOLDS ON the Palladist group.
Jacqueline, still running, comes into the scene and goes the steps. She opens the front door and lets herself in.

The gas light has been turned down so that there is only tiny flame to illuminate the hall. The draft in the hallw stirs this little flame and the shadows move with it. Jacqueline comes up the stairs. Now that she can be seen closely, it can be seen also that she is exhausted, her e wild, her hair in disorder. She almost staggers as she reaches the landing and goes slowly supporting herself on banisters, toward Mary's door. Her way brings her past Ro #7, the room with the noose. For a moment she stands weak staring at the door, then goes on. She has reached Mary's room, has crossed the narrow hallway and her hand is almo on the knob when Mimi's door opens and Mimi, white nightВ—gowned, comes out into the eerie gas light. Jacque looks at her face which is distorted and horrible in the moving shadows and flickering light. She stifles a scream The other girl is also frightened. The two stand staring each other for a moment.
(weakly) Who are you?
I'm Mimi -- I'm dying.
No!
Yes. It's been quiet, oh ever so quiet. I hardly move, yet it keeps coming all the time -В—closer and closer. I rest and rest and yet I am dying.
And you don't want to die. I've always wanted to die -- always.
I'm afraid.
Jacqueline shakes her head.
I'm tired of being afraid -В— of waiting.
Why wait?
(with sudden determination) I'm not going to wait. I'm going out -- laugh, dance --do all the things I used to do.
And then?
I don't know.
(very softly end almost with envy) You will die.

But Mimi has already turned back into her room. Jacquelin stands watching until the light snaps on in Mimi's room a then the door closing, plunges the hall into weird half l again. In this semi-darkness, she turns away from Mary's and walks down the hall toward room #7. She opens the doo and goes in. For a brief moment the light from the hall c the shadow of a noose against the further wall of the roo and then the door closes behind her.

The room is lit by a single little lamp on the dressing t В— Mary herself stands near the window, looking out. Greg is talking over the telephone. From downstairs we hear Mr Romari singing. The song comes faintly to this upper stor She is singing an Italian song. The words are Dante's:
(singing) Death, why hast thou made life so hard to bear, Taking my lady hence? East thou no whit or shame? The youngest flowers and the most fair Thou hast pluck'd. away and the world wanteth it.
Gregory puts down the telephone and crosses to the window
That was Dr. Judd. He was phoning to say that, Jacqueline is on her way here -
Gregory В—В— (pauses then goes on) you'd better take Jacqueline with you tonight.
It's what I should have done yesterday. I'll take her away somewhere where she can rest.
Mary turns back toward the window. Gregory stands watchin her.
Mary.
She turns toward him. He puts his hands on her shoulders turns her back to the window.
No. Stay that way. I want to talk to you. I love you -В— you know that?
(in a choked voice ) Yes.
Perhaps, later, when things are settled, when Jacqueline's well again -- maybe we can arrange things differently.
Mary turns and faces him.
I've never loved any one before, Gregory, and I do love you -В— you must know it -- but Jacqueline's my sister В—В— whom I had lost and have found again.... (breaks off,) (shaking her) (head)
I know В—В— I shouldn't have told youВ—
No, I'm glad....at least I've heard you say it...
Mary shakes her head, turns back toward the window. They stand together for a moment. From below comes the sound o Mrs. Romari's singing.

The CAMERA IS LEVELED on the empty hall. From downstairs can be heard the sound of Mrs. Romari singing. Then Mimi' door opens and Mimi sweeps out, dressed in a black dress, gleaming with sequins, her hair piled high, her walk prou and steady. She comes down the hall toward the camera. Ju as she reaches the door of #7, there is the sound of an overВ—turned chair falling. She pauses and looks toward t door. There is the creaking sound of the rope. She listen for an instant, and failing to comprehend, sweeps on past camera.

It is a bright day and the sunlit street can be seen thro the windows. Children are hurrying by on their way to sch At a table near the window Mary sits with Gregory. She ha been crying and has her sodden handkerchief in her hand. Gregory has a pre-occupied air and is tracing figures on table cloth with his fork. Jason comes in bearing a small tray with three tiny cups coffee on it. He puts a cup in front of each of them and keeps one for himself. He sips his coffee. Neither Mary nor Gregory touch theirs Jason pushes Mary's toward her to attract her attention, She picks it up and brings it to her lips.
I hate people who try to peddle comfort. But,Mary, you shouldn't mourn for Jacqueline. Life for her was full of the agony of a disordered mind. It's better this way.
I keep telling myself that.
Well, tell yourself, Mary, that this is a world that doesn't pass with the passing of any one of us. All three of us are going to start afresh.
He looks up and across at Jason with a meaningful glance Mary.
You and I have new hopes В—В— and new plans can come from them В—В—
Jason looks at him across Mary and shakes his head.

Not I В—- I am alive, yet every hope I had is dead, (turns to Mary) Death can be good. Death can be happy.. If I were really dying I could speak like Cyrano -В— "My courage like a white plume" В— and all the other lovely words with which he greeted death. Then perhaps you might understand,
(reaching over to touch  (his band) I understand.
(suddenly) Good. We all understand each other. You, Gregory and I. We all know. There is sunlight in the streets and work to do. Both of you -В— you're off to work.
He gets up and takes Mary's arm, helping her to rise.
Off with you. You can't sit here in this cellar with the sun shining.

He hustles her toward the door and Gregory follows. Mary Gregory ascend the steps to the street level. Jason steps back a pace or two so that he is backgrounded the mural of Dante. He stands there, and the smile leaves face. His whole body reflects his hopelessness and despai It is at this moment that Mrs. Romari comes hustling in f the kitchen.
Ah! Good! They have all gone! Now you and I can laugh and joke again.
He turns to her, forcing a smile.
